Part Name: *note that I get a small commission off these Amazon links, but this is where I buy a lot of my supplies anyway.
I recommend checking your local hardware store first, as many of these materials are available there, consider these links more of a reference than a specific brand requirement.

Notes: Only about 1.5" of this is needed for cutting shaft collars.
McMaster does not sell 360 ultra machinable brass in thinner sheets. I used the 353 brass instead, it is also very machinable.

Part Name: n/a – you will only need a tiny scrap of silver colored metal
Notes: This is to add a silver tooth to the calendar dial to mark a special date.  Use a piece of scrap.  I used aluminum.

Part Name: 1/16" OD tight tolerance stainless steel rod 6" length
Notes: Only a few inches needed.  Brass also available.

Part Name: 1/8" OD tight tolerance stainless steel rod 12" length
Notes: I think it's worth it to pay the extra for tight-tolerance on these rods - makes the press fits more reliable and saves some filing work later, but McMaster also sells a standard tolerance version of these rods for 1/3 the price. Brass also available, though I ended up liking the look of the mixed metals more.

Part Name: *Note from McMaster: Tubes with 0.014" and 0.45 mm wall thicknesses allow you to create telescoping tubes; each tube fits inside the next larger size.  I went with imperial sizes because McMaster tends to have more inventory in inches than mm that would be compatible with the tubes.

**These brass tubes are used widely and can often be found at the local hardware/craft store.  Some interesting ideas about working this these tubes here: http://steampunkworkshop.com/making-joints-telescoping-brass-tubing-slip-fit-press-fit-detent-fit/
***McMaster does not sell tubes in the 360 brass. The 260 brass has a slightly different color than the 360, but it is not very noticeable.

Notes: Only a few inches needed.
Only a few inches needed.
Only a few inches needed.
Only a few inches needed, used for central drive.  A 1/4" rod would also work, but was too small for my lathe chuck.

Part Name: *I laser cut this stock to the correct washer sizes I needed. Double thick washers in the CAD model are made from two layers of washers.

**These washers could be made out of anything (like standard metal washers), it's not critical to be low friction because the parts of this machine don't move that fast - laser cutting them myself was cheaper and easier for me because I could control the size.

Notes: Only about a foot needed.

Part Name: 10 pack bearing for 1/8" shaft with 1/4" OD and 7/64" height
Notes: These bearings are $1 each on Amazon - since this isn't a high performance application, I don't care about quality too much. If Amazon is not an option for you, the bearings could be subbed with these (much more expensive) bearings from McMaster.

Part Name: *you should check out your local hardware store first to see if you can buy these screws individually, as very few per pack are used.

Notes: Tiny screw for the moon shaft collar, you could also file down a 4mm screw to achieve this.
Shaft collar sets screw for various parts.
Set screws for the two shaft collars that were turned on the lathe and the crank handle.  M2 screws would work here too, but the M2.5 have more grip.
Used for the bottom mount on on the central axis, a smaller screw would work here (e.g. M2.5), but the M3 are better if you can swing it.
Used for crank adjustments (inside threaded inserts).  This is an odd part bc it is so long, you can also use regular M3 bolt, but you'll have to figure out how long you need based on your setup

Part Name: 1/4-20 stainless set screw 3/8" length, 1/8" drive size
Notes: For sun attachment to central shaft.

Part Name: 6-32 brass set screw 1/8" length, 1/16" drive size
Notes: For moon and counterweight attachment.
These screw into the wood base for adjustment mechanism for worm gear meshing alignment.  I found needed to install these in a slightly larger hole than recommended on McMaster's website.
McMaster's brass standoffs have a zinc coating, so I'm just using the smallest, cheapest metal standoffs available. For the final finish, I've added a bit of brass tube around the standoff.

Part Name: #2 1/4" decorative round head brass wood screws
Notes: For mounting the nameplate to the underside of the wood base.
McMaster's brass standoffs have a zinc coating, so I'm just using the smallest, cheapest metal standoffs available. For the final finish, I've added a brass tube around the standoff.

For attaching the moon orbit cam to its mount (these will need to be shortened a little bit, but McMaster does not carry shorter lengths).  I would have liked to use a decorative round head screw for this, but had trouble sourcing.

9 used for final assembly, also used about 20 screws to fixture 1/8" and 3/16" brass stock for machining.  The important thing about these screws is that they will fit inside an 1/8" hole without damaging the surface finish.  The square drive prevents stripping.
Only for fixturing, not used for final assembly.

Part Name: *convenient but optional, these could be made from the 1/16" rod

Notes: I used domestic cherry.
Only a few square inches needed.  Not visible from the outside, any color is fine.  Also used for gear depthing gauge (see below).
Many other styles available, should be at least 1" in height.
Order early, may ship from china.  Will need to bore the worm wheel out to 1/4" ID.  This 40:1 worm drive could also be nice, but 3D model will need to be adjusted.
Stiffer option: 3mm x 10mm x 0.5mm compression spring

Part Name: *These inlaid beads vary a lot in quality, so take a close look at the pictures before ordering, I found a really nice one on AlphaStamps, but it doesn't look like they are selling this part anymore.
**I liked the slightly abstract representation of Earth that I got from these handmade globe beads, but if you want something more realistic, you could have one 3D printed on Shapeways.

Notes: These can be sourced from Etsy, John F Allen, and ZnetShows (among other places), note that the quality varies greatly from source to source.

Part Name: In case you don't want to epoxy the calendar dial to the wood base, an option is to fasten it magnetically.

Notes: This is cut into small pieces and epoxied to the backside of the brass calendar plate to attach it to the magnets

Num Per Container: <<< $100 dollars of that is for screws, of which you only use a few $ worth, I recommend buying screws individually to cut costs.

Notes: I would have liked to use a 2 flute cutter for better chip clearance, but these were really cheap and I've been happy with their performance.

Part Name: 1/16" 2 flute upcutter end mill (>1/8" length of cut) (for metal)
3/64" 2 flute upcutter end mill (1/8" length of cut) (for metal)
Notes: Get extras, these are easy to break.

Part Name: 1/32" 2 flute upcutter end mill (1/8" length of cut) (for metal)
Notes: Get extras, these are very easy to break.
The tip breaks when cutting into brass with these, but it still works.

Part Name: 1/4" 2 flute ball nose end mill (for wood)

Notes: I have this metric one because I tend to use metric screws in other projects, exact sizes don't really matter.
At some point I'd like to modify this set to work better for brass.

Optional - I used this to add a slight chamfer to some holes before press fitting, reaming, or opening up the holes to a larger diameter.  I just held the tool in my hand to do this chamfering very lightly.  You can also use the tip of a large drill bit for this.

I got this set from Amazon, you can use the 1/16" drill to make the hole for the M2 threads (1/16 ~= 1.6mm), the M2.5 requires a 2.0mm drill, M3 requires a 2.5mm drill.  I got the smaller drill sizes from this pin vise set (the pin vise also comes in handy for this project).

Optional – I found that I needed this tap for the moon shaft collar (the smallest part), where there was very little clearance to cut threads.  You could also tap all the way through the part or use Loctite 603 here to bond the shaft collar to the shaft and avoid buying another tool.

I haven't used this part from Amazon specifically, but it seems like it would work.  You'll need tap handles that go down to M2, which is somewhat unusual.  I like these types of tap handles because I can drill a small center hole in the top and use the tap guide to center the tapping on the mill or drill press.
Optional  I find these handy.
You can also use a sharp nail and hammer for the same effect.
For cutting tabs on brass stock.

Part Name: small flathead screwdriver (like one from this set)

Notes: For driving M2 set screws.
Something like this - you will need to find something that fits in your setup.
Something like this - you will need to find something that fits in your setup.
I have a Lortone tumble polisher, but this looks similar.

Part Name: 2lbs tumble polisher stainless steel shot media

Notes: Obviously there are much nicer calipers out there, but if you're just starting, I'd recommend getting something you won't have to worry about too much if you accidently drop.
Obviously there are much nicer micrometers out there, but if you're just starting, I'd recommend getting something you won't have to worry about too much if you accidently drop.

Part Name: Knurlmaster Standard Kit hand knurler (optional, but handy)
Notes: I ordered this with the fine tooth straight knurls installed instead of the regular straight knurls.
For melting engraver's wax, get one prefilled with butane.
For glueing up wood base, it's also possible to use regular clamps for this.
This is a tool that will need to be made to help accurately position the gear axes.

Part Name: This is a very simple (and probably much less accurate) version of Clickspring's tool described here.

In addition to the parts listed here, I also used some of the acrylic for the body of the gauge and some of the 1/8" stainless rod (filed to be a slip fit in the undersized gear holes).  These materials are listed elsewhere in the BOM.

Notes: This is a fine-tune adjustment screw for the gauge, aim for 30-50mm in length.  You will probably never use a screw with these dimensions again, so I recommend going to the local hardware store and buying the longest single M3 you can get rather than a whole box, I got a 30mm socket head screw.
For tapping and reaming.
For final assembly.

I really liked this Mohawk ultra flow lacquer spray in clear gloss.  I actually used the satin finish for most of my parts, but would go for glossy next time since you can bring it to a satin finish with 0000 steel wool.  I did use the ultra flow gloss finish on the engravings and was very happy with the results after about 3 coats.  Other brands I saw recommended were Nikolas and Staybrite.  I went with the aerosol spray for convenience, but many suggest dipping in thinned lacquer for better results (so far I have not figured out a good strategy for doing this).  If you don't want to use lacquer, you might check out Renaissance Wax.
Don't use acetone on the engravings, it will melt the wax!
The acid reacts with the surface of the brass to remove oxidation and give it a whiter appearance.  Some recommend lemi shine for this, I found that the white vinegar works just as well.
Cutting up an old cotton t-shirt works.
For applying a fine brushed finish to brass.
Use this wet to reduce dust.
I use the lighter color sandpaper on wood so it doesn't leave any black oxides on my piece.

For darkening the letters on the dial - I originally tried using jax black patina, but didn't end up getting a dark enough result.  Another source for the wax that I believe would be comparable is a "lacquer burn in stick": https://www.lmii.com/fretting-setup-tools/3051-burn-in-lacquer-stick-black-34-oz.html
I like using scotch tape, stronger tapes may make your workpiece too difficult to remove.
For tumble polishing.
I screwed down the brass to this to fix it in the vise during machining.  I'm able to resurface this same piece and use it again for many projects, amortizing the cost.

Part Name: 3 axis CNC mill - I used a Tormach PCNC 1100
Notes: Since this project uses very small bits, a high RPM spindle is better (though you will need the option to slow down to about 2K RPM for some of the reaming/drilling operations). The machine I used only went up to about 6k; I think I could have gone a lot faster with a higher RPM machine.

Part Name: 3 axis CNC mill (for cutting wood) – I used a Shopbot PRS Alpha
Notes: I can't cut wood on the Tormach because of the coolant system, so I used the Shopbot instead.
Not strictly necessary, but it was useful drilling/tapping and for facing off some of my parts when the stock was a bit too thick.
There are two brass shaft collars and a thick-walled aluminum tube that had to be made for this project.  Theoretically, they could also be made on the CNC.
For making jigs for drilling angled holes in Earth mount and moon cam shaft collar.  The angled holes could be cut without the jigs with a bit more effort.
For cutting rod/tube stock.
For dimensioning rod/tube stock, removing tabs from gears.
For pressing together press fit joints.
For cutting wood pre-glueup.
For planing wood post-glueups.
